parts.instructions: You are going to read an article about archaeological discoveries. For questions 1-6, choose the answer (A, B, C or D) which you think fits best according to the text.

passage.title: Uncovering the Past
passage.content:
Dr. Isabella Martinez carefully brushed sand away from what appeared to be a piece of ancient pottery. After three weeks of excavation at the Serrano Valley site, her team had uncovered artifacts that could rewrite the history of early civilization in the region.

'What we're finding here challenges everything we thought we knew about this period,' Isabella explained to her research assistant, Carlos. The pottery fragments they had discovered showed sophisticated artistic techniques that weren't supposed to exist until centuries later.

The discovery began when local farmers reported finding unusual objects while preparing fields for planting. Isabella's team from the Regional Archaeological Institute was called in to investigate. What they expected to be a routine survey turned into one of the most significant finds of the decade.

The site revealed evidence of a previously unknown civilization that had mastered advanced metallurgy and ceramic techniques. 'These people were far more sophisticated than we gave them credit for,' Isabella noted. 'They had developed technologies that we thought emerged much later in human history.'

However, the excavation faced numerous challenges. Funding was limited, and the team had to work quickly before the rainy season made the site inaccessible. Additionally, some local residents were concerned about the impact of archaeological work on their farming activities.

Isabella worked closely with the community to address these concerns. 'Archaeological research shouldn't disrupt local livelihoods,' she emphasized. 'We've trained several community members to assist with the excavation, providing them with new skills while preserving their cultural heritage.'

The team's most remarkable discovery was a series of underground chambers containing well-preserved manuscripts and artistic works. 'These documents could provide unprecedented insights into how these ancient people lived, worked, and understood their world,' Isabella explained. The preservation was so exceptional that even organic materials had survived nearly intact.

As news of the discovery spread, international researchers expressed interest in collaborating. Isabella welcomed this attention but insisted that the local community remain central to all research efforts. 'This is their heritage,' she concluded. 'Any research must benefit them as much as it advances our academic understanding.'

parts.instructions: You are going to read an article about space exploration. Six paragraphs have been removed from the article. Choose from the paragraphs A-G the one which fits each gap (7-12). There is one extra paragraph which you do not need to use.

passage.title: The New Space Race
passage.content:
Private companies are revolutionizing space exploration, making what once seemed impossible increasingly achievable. This new era of commercial spaceflight is changing how we think about humanity's future beyond Earth.

[7]

The cost of launching satellites and supplies to space has decreased dramatically over the past decade. This reduction has made space more accessible to smaller nations, research institutions, and private companies.

[8]

Reusable rocket technology represents one of the most significant breakthroughs in space transportation. Instead of discarding expensive rocket components after a single use, companies can now land and refurbish them for future missions.

[9]

Space tourism is no longer confined to science fiction. Several companies now offer civilian flights to the edge of space, with longer orbital trips planned for the near future.

[10]

The implications extend far beyond recreational travel. Commercial space stations could serve as research laboratories, manufacturing facilities, and stepping stones to more distant destinations like Mars.

[11]

International cooperation remains essential despite the commercial competition. Space exploration requires sharing resources, expertise, and risks among multiple nations and organizations.

[12]

As we stand on the threshold of becoming a truly spacefaring civilization, the decisions made today will determine whether space exploration benefits all of humanity or remains the privilege of a few.

paragraphs.text: This technological advancement has reduced launch costs by up to 90%, making space ventures economically viable for a broader range of participants.
However, critics argue that space tourism diverts resources from more pressing Earth-based problems like climate change and poverty.
These developments have sparked concerns about space traffic management and the need for international regulations in Earth's orbit.
Unlike government-funded space programs of the past, private companies operate with greater flexibility and faster decision-making processes.
This shift in economics has enabled innovative projects that would have been financially impossible under traditional space program models.
These early space tourists are helping to fund the infrastructure development needed for more ambitious missions.
Successful international partnerships in space have historically led to improved diplomatic relationships on Earth.

parts.instructions: You are going to read about four people who work in creative industries. For questions 13-22, choose from the people (A-D). The people may be chosen more than once.

people.name: Sofia Gonzalez - Film Editor
people.text: I spend months working on projects that audiences watch in just a few hours, but every second matters. Film editing is like solving a massive puzzle where you're constantly rearranging pieces to create the perfect story flow. I work closely with directors to understand their vision, but often I see possibilities they haven't considered. The technology has evolved dramatically since I started fifteen years ago - what once required expensive equipment now fits on a laptop. My favorite projects are documentaries because they allow me to help reveal important truths about our world. The pressure can be intense, especially near deadlines, but there's incredible satisfaction in creating something that moves people emotionally.

people.name: Marcus Chen - Video Game Designer
people.text: Creating virtual worlds requires balancing creativity with technical constraints. I design gameplay mechanics, storylines, and character interactions for role-playing games. The development process typically takes three to five years from concept to release. Player feedback is crucial - we constantly test and refine gameplay elements based on user experience. The gaming industry is highly competitive, and commercial success often depends on timing and market trends. I'm passionate about creating inclusive games that represent diverse perspectives and experiences. Collaboration is essential since modern games require teams of artists, programmers, writers, and sound designers working together.

people.name: Diana Rodriguez - Textile Artist
people.text: I create large-scale fabric installations for museums and public spaces. My work explores themes of cultural identity and environmental conservation through traditional weaving techniques combined with modern materials. Each piece takes months of planning and execution, often involving community workshops where I teach traditional crafts to younger generations. The physical demands are significant - my studio work requires hours of detailed hand-weaving and dyeing. Funding is always challenging since textile art is sometimes considered less prestigious than painting or sculpture. However, I've found that my work resonates strongly with audiences who appreciate the connection between craft traditions and contemporary social issues.

people.name: Robert Kim - Music Producer
people.text: I work with emerging artists to develop their sound and create professional recordings. The music industry has changed dramatically with streaming platforms - artists now need to constantly release new content to maintain audience attention. My studio operates 24/7 during busy periods, and I often work with musicians who have very different creative processes and personalities. Technical skills are important, but understanding the emotional core of a song is what makes the difference between good and great productions. I've learned that the best recordings often happen during unexpected moments rather than in formal studio sessions. Building long-term relationships with artists is more valuable than one-hit successes.
